column3: 2017 2nd Quarter Fatalities/Near FatalitiesApril 1 to June 30, 2017 1FatalitiesButler County

1. A 4-year-old male child died on March 21, 2017, as a result of physical abuse. ButlerCounty Children and Youth Services (BCCYS) substantiated the case on May 19, 2017,naming the child’s mother’s paramour as the perpetrator. On March 21, 2017, themother left the child in the care of her paramour around 6:00 AM. Later that morning,the paramour contacted his own mother to transport the child to the child’s father’sresidence. While driving, the child became unresponsive. At 9:36 AM, the paramour’smother contacted 911 to seek assistance for the child while pulled over in a parking lot.EMS performed cardiopulmonary resuscitation while transporting the child to the localhospital. The child was pronounced dead at 10:15 AM. The child had sustained multipleinjuries including rectal bleeding, extensive bruising from blunt force trauma, and asecond-degree burn. The mother reported the child appeared healthy when she left forwork that morning. The paramour could not be located by local law enforcement untilMarch 23, 2017, when he was found hiding in his mother’s attic. The half-sibling wasmedically evaluated and determined to be healthy with no injuries and was placed in afoster home. The paramour was arrested on March 27, 2017, and incarcerated. He wascharged with criminal homicide, involuntary deviate sexual intercourse with a child withserious bodily injury, rape of a child, rape of a child with serious bodily injury,aggravated indecent assault of a child, aggravated assault, endangering the welfare ofchildren, and recklessly endangering another person. The mother was arrested andcharged on March 27, 2017, with two counts of endangering the welfare of children. Shewas released on bond and is awaiting trial. The paramour’s mother was arrested onMarch 24, 2017, and charged with two felony counts of hindering apprehension,endangering the welfare of children, and recklessly endangering another person. Sheremains incarcerated awaiting trial. BCCYS substantiated two additional child protective services (CPS) reports received on April 24, 2017. The first CPS report alleged themother, maternal grandmother, and the mother’s paramour’s mother failed to providemedical treatment to the victim child when he sustained the second degree thermal burnto his left hand prior to the fatality incident. The second CPS report alleged the mother’sparamour’s mother failed to provide the victim child with timely medical services onMarch 21, 2017, when she first became knowledgeable of the victim child’s injuriesrelated to the fatality incident. She did not contact emergency medical services until thevictim child became unresponsive. The mother is currently receiving drug and alcoholcounseling, individual therapy, and supervised visitation with the child’s half-sibling.The family had a prior history with BCCYS. Three general protective services reportswere received between August 2014 to January 2017 due to concerns for drug andalcohol use and domestic violence. One CPS report was received due to an injury to thechild that was unfounded.Chester County

2. A 10-month-old female died on April 27, 2017, as a result of serious physical neglect.On June 23, 2017, Chester County Children and Youth (CCCY) named the father as theperpetrator. The victim child was residing in the home of her father. The father statedthat he laid the child down for a nap around 6:00 PM. He went to check on her around8:00 PM and found her unconscious. The father called emergency medical services2017 2nd Quarter Fatalities/Near FatalitiesApril 1 to June 30, 2017 2(EMS) and the child was pronounced dead upon their arrival. An autopsy revealed nosigns of trauma, however the toxicology report has not been received. It is suspected thechild ingested the father’s medication. The father told law enforcement that the child may have been ingesting the pills since December 2016. There are no other children inthe home. The mother and father are separated due to domestic violence and she wasnot residing in the home at the time of the incident. The father has been arrested withcharges pending toxicology results. The mother and father of the victim child were notknown to Chester County. The mother was known to Berks County Children and Youth(BCCY). Two general protective services referrals were received in 2002 that the childrenwere dirty, had poor housing conditions, and there was a lack of supervision. In-home services were provided and closed in 2004. In 2010, BCCY received another report ofpoor housing conditions and lack of supervision. BCCY did not open the case forservices. In June 2016, BCCY was contacted when the victim child was born due toconcerns about the mother’s housing which was resolved when she and the child movedinto the father’s home.Clinton County

3. A 3-year-old male child died on May 24, 2017, as a result of serious physical neglect.Clinton County Children and Youth (CCYS) indicated the case on June 26, 2017,naming the child’s mother as the perpetrator. On the day of the incident, the mother,father, victim child, and the victim child’s 1-year-old sibling were staying at the paternalgrandparent’s home. On the morning of May 24, 2017, the mother fell asleep while beingthe sole caretaker of her two children. She woke up approximately 1 hour and 40minutes later and noticed a stool by the door and the door unlocked. The motherreported looking outside the home for the child, then calling her sister, the paternalgrandfather, and the paternal grandmother. A search of the neighborhood ensued by allparties. The grandmother found the victim child floating face up in a neighbor’s pool.She removed the child from the pool and started cardiopulmonary resuscitation.Emergency medical services (EMS) transported the child to the hospital; however, thehospital physician reported the child died before EMS arrived at the home. There wereno other signs of trauma. The 1-year-old sibling was placed in foster care to ensuresafety. CCYS offered the family services however the family declined. The child currentlyresides in kinship foster care with supervised visits from both parents. Charges are pending with the mother with the next court hearing scheduled for November 6, 2017.The family was previously known to CCYS. Between August 2014 and September 2015there were two referrals for substance use and lack of stable housing. CCYS assisted thefamily with housing, meeting the medical needs of the children, and drug and alcoholcounseling. In October 2016, another referral was received for parental substance usethat was invalidated and closed. In January 2017, there was a referral for substance use and inadequate hygiene that was invalidated in March 2017.Lancaster County

4. A 3-year-old female child died on April 28, 2017, as a result of serious physical neglect.Lancaster County Children and Youth Agency (LCCYA) indicated the case on June 27,2017, naming the child’s mother as the perpetrator. On the date of the incident, thevictim child was on the couch in the living room with the mother. The father of the childand a 14-year-old female sibling were also in the home, but were on the second level ofthe house. The mother fell asleep and the child was able to open an unlocked door to thebackyard, leave the home and fall into the pool. When the mother woke up after an2017 2nd Quarter Fatalities/Near FatalitiesApril 1 to June 30, 2017 3unknown amount of time, she found the child face down in the pool. The mother initiallyattempted to retrieve the child but was unable to swim and had to hold onto the side ofthe pool. The 14-year-old sibling heard the mother screaming and retrieved the childfrom the pool. The sibling attempted cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) but wasunable to revive the child. Emergency medical services arrived at the home and alsoperformed CPR, but were not able to revive the child. It was determined that neither thesibling nor father were in a caregiver role at the time of the incident and, therefore, didnot have responsibility in ensuring that the victim child was supervised. It wasdetermined the mother was responsible for the care of the child at the time of theincident. Both parents were however charged with endangering the welfare of children asit was determined that the mother was under the influence of cocaine and marijuanaand the father admitted to using cocaine in the days leading up to the event. Bothparents posted bail and are awaiting preliminary hearings. LCCYA aided the sibling inobtaining school-based counseling. The parents declined offered services. The family waspreviously known to LCCYA. A general protective services report was received in January2016 for possible drug use in the home that was invalidated.Lawrence County

5. A 16-month-old male died on March 27, 2017, as a result of physical abuse. LawrenceCounty Children and Youth Services (LCCYS) indicated the case on May 4, 2017,naming the child’s father as the perpetrator. The father reported that on the day of theincident he had gotten up and gone to the kitchen at approximately 4:00 AM. He heard athud and found the child on the floor in the bedroom. He reported he thought the childfell out of bed bumping a table holding a television, causing the television to fall on him.He stated the child was limp but alert. The child was taken to the paternalgrandmother’s apartment next door and 911 was called. A computerized axialtomography (CAT) scan showed an acute subdural hematoma, multiple old bruises, aswell as a round mark on his leg of undetermined nature. The child needed surgery forthe subdural hematoma. While in surgery the child became unstable andcardiopulmonary resuscitation was administered for 45 minutes; the child waspronounced dead at 9:15 AM. According to physicians, the child’s injuries wereconsistent with shaking and shearing effects of abusive head trauma, with indicationsthat the injury occurred shortly prior to the victim becoming unresponsive. There wereno other children in the home. The mother resides in another state. This incidentoccurred while the child was visiting his father. Criminal charges are pending the resultsof the coroner’s report. The family was found to have no prior children and youthservices involvement in the mother’s state of residence or Pennsylvania.Lebanon County

6. A 15-month-old child died on April 25, 2017, as a result of serious physical neglect.Lebanon County Children and Youth Services (LCCYS) indicated the case on June 1,2017, naming the child’s mother and father as perpetrators. According to the mother,she found the child at 7:30 AM after coming home from work. The child was reportedlystiff and blue standing up in his crib while the father was asleep. The mother moved thechild from the master bedroom to the living room to try and revive the child while the father called 911. Emergency medical services (EMS) were called and the child waspronounced dead at the home. An autopsy was performed, and the child was found tohave bruising across his chest and back, along with bruises under his chin. Duringinterviews with the four other siblings in the home, it was learned that both parents2017 2nd Quarter Fatalities/Near FatalitiesApril 1 to June 30, 2017 4would place a mattress and bags of rock salt on top of the crib and hold everything downwith a bungee cord to keep the child from getting out of his crib. The bruises werethought to be a result of the child’s struggle to get out from under the mattress. A safetyplan is in place with two half-siblings living with their biological father and two siblingsliving with their paternal grandmother along with the parents. The parents are not to bealone with the children. Both have been referred for parenting skills training and mentalhealth evaluations. The father was referred for a drug and alcohol evaluation. Theparents have been charged with involuntary manslaughter and endangering the welfareof a child. The family was not known to LCCYS prior to this incident.Monroe County

7. A 9-year-old male child died on March 12, 2017, as a result of physical abuse. MonroeCounty Children and Youth Services (MCCYS) indicated the case on April 11, 2017,naming the child’s mother as the perpetrator. On the date of the incident, the motherinformed the father that she was going for a ride with the victim child. The fatherremained in the family residence with the 13- and 15-year-old sisters of the victim child.While sitting in the family vehicle in the driveway of the home, the mother shot the childin the head and then shot herself. Before the shooting, the mother called 911 from thevehicle. When emergency services arrived at the home, both the mother and child weredeceased. There was no evidence that the father or siblings had any knowledge of themother’s plan. The child had been diagnosed with Asperger’s and attended an emotionalsupport classroom. The siblings remain in the care of the father. MCCYS offeredsupportive services to the family as well as referral services for grief counseling. Thefamily had no prior involvement with the MCCYS.Philadelphia County

8. A 3-month-old male child died on March 23, 2017, as a result of physical abuse. ThePhiladelphia Department of Human Services (PDHS) indicated the case on April 21,2017, naming the child’s father as the perpetrator. On March 20, 2017, the mother leftthe house taking the child’s sibling. At 10:00 AM the father called the mother and statedthe victim child was not moving but was breathing. The child reportedly soundedcongested and the father was advised to take the child to the bathroom and run hotwater to make steam. The father and mother remained in contact until the father textedthe mother and stated the child had stopped breathing. When emergency medicalservices arrived at approximately 11:30 AM the child had no pulse. The child wastransported to a local hospital where a computerized axial tomography (CAT) scanrevealed subdural and subarachnoid hemorrhages on the brain, a small laceration onhis chin and bruising on his neck. The petechial eye and subdural injuries weredetermined to be due to lack of oxygen. The child died on March 23, 2017, due tocardiopulmonary arrest as a result of non-accidental injuries. The father wasdetermined to be the sole caretaker at the time the injuries occurred. A 6-year-oldsibling who also resided in the home was examined and found to have no injuries orconcerns for abuse. The sibling was placed with a maternal aunt until a safetyassessment was completed. On June 21, 2017, this child was returned to the legal andphysical custody of her mother. The father was arrested on March 28, 2017, andcharged with murder. PDHS provided case management services to the mother andsibling as well as trauma and grief counseling. PDHS did not know the family prior tothe incident.2017 2nd Quarter Fatalities/Near FatalitiesApril 1 to June 30, 2017 5

9. A 1-month-old male child died on May 26, 2017, as the result of physical abuse.Philadelphia Department of Human Services (PDHS) indicated the case on June 27,2017, naming the child’s father and mother as perpetrators. The child was reported tobe taken to a local hospital by his parents due to a nose bleed. The child had no pulsewhen he arrived at the hospital. A computerized axial tomography (CAT) scan of hisbrain revealed bilateral subdural hematoma, subarachnoid hemorrhage, cerebral edema,bilateral retinal hemorrhages with possible retinal detachment. The severe head traumaand internal injuries were consistent with child abuse. The parents had no explanationfor the child’s injuries stating he was fine until blood started coming from his nose.Later, the father reported that the child had fallen off an air mattress while in his care,and that he had “tossed” the child onto an air mattress and a bouncy chair. The fatherdenied shaking or punching the child. He did state that the child was crying but thenbegan to breathe heavily. When he picked the child up, the child was lifeless. There wereno other children in the home. Law enforcement arrested the father on May 26, 2017,and he remains in custody charged with murder and endangering the welfare of a child.This family had recently moved and was known to Delaware County Children and Youth(DCCYS). DCCYS received a general protective services (GPS) report when the child andmother tested positive for opiates at his birth. The report was determined to be validand the family was in need of services. As part of a safety plan the family agreed to moveto Philadelphia to live with the maternal grandfather. On May 15, 2017, the case wasreferred to PDHS. At the time of the incident, PDHS was investigating this GPS reportbut the PDHS worker could not locate the family prior to the child’s death. The motherand child had moved to the father’s home in violation of the safety plan.

10. A 13-year-old female child died on February 28, 2017, as a result of serious physicalneglect. Philadelphia Department of Human Services (PDHS) indicated the case on May1, 2017, naming the child’s mother as perpetrator. On February 28, 2017, the child wasadmitted to a local pediatric intensive care hospital after developing a fever of 104° F;she died later that day. The mother denied the child showed any symptoms of illness on February 27, 2017. She admitted to monitoring the child’s temperature on February 28,2017, but delayed seeking treatment until the child collapsed. The mother confirmedthat she had received education about sickle cell disease and stated she was aware sheneeded to seek medical attention if the child’s temperature was 101° F or greater due torisk of bacterial infections. The child had a history of medical issues and infections.There were no other children in the home. PDHS had no previous knowledge of thisfamily.

11. A 2-year-old male child died on March 22, 2017, as a result of serious physical neglect.On May 2, 2017, the Philadelphia Department of Human Services (PDHS) indicated boththe mother and the mother’s paramour. On March 22, 2017, law enforcement respondedto a report that the body of the child was at the mother’s paramour’s apartment. Lawenforcement found the deceased child alone in the home, naked, and emaciated. Thechild was pronounced dead by the medical examiner’s office on the scene. The motheradmitted that she dropped the child off at the paramour’s apartment on February 14,2017, and did not visually check on the child from that date until the discovery of the child’s body on March 22, 2017. She reported the paramour told her that the child wasbeing cared for by other trusted individuals. Upon interview, the paramour reported that she left the child alone in her apartment on February 14, 2017. She returned later thatday after smoking “K2” (marijuana laced with PCP) and saw the child slumped over acouch with white foam emanating from the child’s mouth. The paramour admitted to2017 2nd Quarter Fatalities/Near FatalitiesApril 1 to June 30, 2017 6leaving the child in that position without checking for vital signs or informing the motheror authorities. The paramour was arrested and charged with endangering the welfare ofa child, concealing the child’s death, and abuse of corpse and other related crimes in thedeath of the child. Any charges related to homicide are pending the outcome of themedical examiner’s report. The paramour is currently incarcerated and is awaiting trial.Charges have not been filed against the mother at this time. The child had a 5-year-oldsister who was being cared for by a relative at the time of the incident. On April 19,2017, a court hearing was held, and legal custody of the sibling was granted to thematernal grandfather. There was no prior PDHS intervention with the mother and herchildren, but the mother does have a history of involvement with PDHS as a child. Themother’s paramour also has a history with PDHS as a child. The whereabouts of thefather are unknown.York County

12. A 3-year-old female child died on April 23, 2017, as a result of physical abuse. On May19, 2017, York County Office of Children, Youth and Families (YOCYF) indicated thefather and paternal grandmother as the perpetrators. On April 22, 2017, lawenforcement attempted to contact the father and paternal grandmother at their home fora child welfare check when the child did not arrive at a custody exchange site. Severalattempts were made, however no one answered the door. On April 23, 2017, lawenforcement entered the home to find the paternal grandmother deceased from agunshot wound. They also discovered the deceased bodies of the father and victim childin the home with gunshot wounds. They found evidence in the home that themurder/suicide was pre-meditated by the father and paternal grandmother. Neitherfather nor mother have any other children. The family was known to YCCYF. InFebruary 2017, the agency received four general protective services referrals for parentalsubstance use and imminent risk due to domestic violence concerns. The agency invalidated and closed the report on February 14, 2017. No additional services wereprovided. Both the mother and father were known to children and youth agencies inother states as children.2017 2nd Quarter Fatalities/Near FatalitiesApril 1 to June 30, 2017 7Near FatalitiesAllegheny County

13. A 6-year-old female child nearly died on April 1, 2017, as a result of serious physicalneglect. Allegheny County Children, Youth and Families (ACCYF) indicated the case onMay 30, 2017, naming the child’s mother as the perpetrator. The child was transportedto the regional pediatric hospital on April 1, 2017, after a reported fall down the familystairs. While in the hospital, the child had a change in mental status, had pinpointpupils, low heart rate and low blood pressure, all indicative of medication intoxication.On April 4, 2017, it was discovered the child had a near fatal level of Clonidine in hersystem upon admittance to the hospital. The child is prescribed Clonidine, but therewere concerns that the caregiver had given the child an intentionally high level of themedication. The mother was known to the hospital for seeking extensive physical andbehavioral health treatments for the child. The child has a half-sibling who has been living with the maternal grandmother since 2007. The child was placed in the home withher half-sibling and maternal grandmother on April 5, 2017, upon discharge from thehospital. Since discharge and placement with her grandmother, the child’s medicationshave all been discontinued, and she was referred for outpatient therapy. The mother hasbeen referred for intensive outpatient therapy, family behavior resources and medicationmanagement. The mother was charged with endangering the welfare of children on May 15, 2017. There is currently a no-contact order in place for the mother and childdue to the criminal charges. The family was known to ACCYF prior to the incident. Twelve prior referrals were received from May 2007 to November 2016. In 2007 and2008 the agency was involved with the mother and the older half-sibling due to reportsof medical concerns resulting in the older half-sibling being placed with the maternalgrandmother. Beginning in November 2010, the agency began receiving referrals on thevictim child. From November 2010 to November 2016, the agency received seven generalprotective services (GPS) referrals with concerns that included inadequate food,inadequate physical care and medical concerns. The case was accepted for services in with her maternal grandmother in March 2014. The child was placed back with hermother in June 2015, and the case was closed in September 2016 as the child wasassessed to be safe in her mother’s care and community support services were in placefor the mother and the child. The last GPS report prior to this incident was in November2016 regarding concerns of inadequate clothing and food. The report was assessed andclosed as invalid.

14. A 7-week-old male child nearly died on May 23, 2017, as a result of physical abuse.Allegheny County Office of Children, Youth and Families (ACOCYF) substantiated thecase on June 30, 2017, naming the mother and the father as the perpetrators. OnMay 23, 2017, the mother visited the father at the paternal great grandmother’s home.While there, she dropped the child onto the floor. The subsequent medical evaluationrevealed two distinct skull fractures, brain hemorrhaging, and healing rib fractures. Thetreating physician determined that these injuries were caused by more than one impact,and the height of the fall was not sufficient enough to cause either skull fracture. Themother and father were the sole caretakers at the time of the injuries and both weredetermined responsible for causing the child’s injuries. The child was discharged from the hospital on May 25, 2017. Upon discharge, ACOCYF obtained emergency custodyand the child was placed into foster care. The child is the only child of both parents.The mother and the child were residing with maternal relatives, therefore ACOCYF2017 2nd Quarter Fatalities/Near FatalitiesApril 1 to June 30, 2017 8ensured the safety of the maternal relatives’ children, and no identified safety concernswere observed. The child was adjudicated dependent on July 5, 2017, and placed withthe maternal grandmother. No charges were filed on either parent; however, the father iscurrently incarcerated on unrelated charges. The mother is permitted supervisedvisitation with her son in the home of the maternal grandmother and is receivingservices for parenting and transportation. The parents were not known to ACOCYF asparents, but referrals were received regarding concerns for them as children. Thesereferrals were not accepted for services.Bucks County

15. A 17-year-old male child nearly died on April 7, 2017, as a result of serious physicalneglect. Bucks County Children & Youth (BCCY) indicated the case on May 11, 2017,naming the mother as the perpetrator. The mother failed to access appropriate medicalcare for the victim child over an extended period of time. The victim child, who hashereditary pancreatitis and is an insulin-dependent diabetic, was not feeling well for afew days. On April 7, 2017, the victim child had episodes of vomiting and had not beenable to speak coherently since the previous evening. The mother reportedly did notrespond to his needs as she did not have medical cards for the children. On the eveningof April 7, 2017, the victim child was found with his eyes rolling back in his head andwas very cold. The child was taken to a local hospital and then transferred to achildren’s hospital. The victim child had not been seen by an endocrinologist since July 2015; the last prescription given to him was in November 2015. There was concernregarding the victim child’s ability to administer his own insulin as well as the mother’sability to monitor his insulin. Prior to discharge, the victim child and foster parentscompleted training on administering insulin and properly monitoring his sugar levels.The child was discharged from the children’s hospital to the care of a foster familyknown to the child. The child has been referred to supportive services. The victim child’ssiblings are residing with other family members. The mother has not been criminallycharged. The family was known to BCCYS prior to this incident. Three general protectiveservices (GPS) reports were received in October 2016 regarding the overall care of thechildren, medical care of the children, parental substance use, and domestic violence. All referrals were closed as concerns were resolved by the end of November 2016. A GPSreferral was made in December 2016 regarding the well-being of a sibling. It was deemedinvalid. In February 2017, a GPS referral was received regarding domestic violence,substance use, and unclean home conditions. On April 4, 2017, a GPS referral wasreceived regarding the middle and youngest siblings and alleged drug use. BCCY wasinvestigating this GPS when the current incident occurred. On April 9, 2017, a childprotective services report was received regarding the victim child’s need for dental care.This report was unfounded.Cambria County

16. A 3-month-old male child nearly died on April 15, 2017, due to serious physical neglect.Cambria County Children and Youth Services (CCCYS) indicated the case on May 24,2017, naming the child’s mother as the perpetrator as she failed to provide her childwith adequate food and medical care. On April 15, 2017, the child’s mother called 911due to the child being unresponsive and having difficulty breathing. The child wastransported via emergency medical services to a local hospital. The child was found to beseverely malnourished. The child was dehydrated, requiring intubation and fluidhydration. The child was transferred to a pediatric specialty hospital via helicopter due2017 2nd Quarter Fatalities/Near FatalitiesApril 1 to June 30, 2017 9to his critical condition. There were no physical signs of abuse. There were four otherchildren in the home who appeared well. A safety plan was put in place for a 2-year-oldsibling due to the child’s age and being non-verbal. A maternal uncle ensured that thischild would be fed and would not be left unsupervised with the mother. Three oldersiblings reported how they were fed and no concerns were identified related to themreceiving adequate food. Upon discharge from the hospital on May 8, 2017, the victimchild was placed in the care and custody of his father. Since the father lives in anotherstate, the case was referred to the children and youth agency of that state. Due toconcerns regarding the mother’s inability to provide appropriate medical care, CCCYShas initiated services for the mother and her other children. There is an on-goinginvestigation. At this time, no criminal charges have been filed against the mother. Thefamily did not have prior involvement with CCCYS. The child’s mother did haveinvolvement with child welfare in another state. Three referrals were received in October2010, June 2011, and January 2012, each involving marijuana use by the mother. Allthe reports were closed after referrals were made for substance use treatment.Crawford County

17. A 3-year-old female child nearly died on February 8, 2017, as a result of physical abuseand serious physical neglect. Crawford County Children and Youth Services (CCCYS)indicated the case on April 7, 2017, naming the child’s father as the perpetrator. OnFebruary 8, 2017, the father, who was responsible for the care of the children, fell asleepat approximately 3:00 AM. The mother came home from work around 6:00 AM and fedthe children breakfast. The children appeared sleepy, so the mother fell asleep with thechild’s sibling on the couch while the victim child went to sleep with her father. Around8:30 AM, the father woke up and found his pill boxes, each of which had a week’s worthof medication in it, on the bedroom floor. One of the boxes was completely empty,another had half eaten/melted pills around it. The father realized the children were stillsleeping which was uncharacteristic of them. The mother tried to wake up the childrenand found the victim child very drowsy and the sibling was unresponsive. Both childrenwere taken to a local hospital. The victim child was observed for several hours. It wasreported by the medical staff that the child and her sibling were at risk of seizures andexcessive bleeding due to the ingestion of this medication. There are no other children inthe home. The victim child was released to her mother’s care upon discharge from the hospital on February 9, 2017. A safety plan was established whereby the maternalgrandmother cares for the children while the mother works and all of the father’smedications will be placed in either a safe or a lock box. The father is supervised by thepaternal grandmother when the children are in his care. The family had no priorinvolvement with CCCYS, however, per the local hospital this was reportedly the secondincident where the child's sibling ingested the father’s medication. Criminal charges arepending on the father. The case was not accepted for services due to the mother’sprotective capacities. The family was recommended to continue to utilize community

18. A 1-year-old male child nearly died on February 8, 2017, as a result of physical abuseand serious physical neglect. Crawford County Children and Youth Services (CCCYS)indicated the case on April 7, 2017, naming the child’s father as the perpetrator. OnFebruary 8, 2017, the father, who was responsible for the care of the children, fell asleepat approximately 3:00 AM. The mother came home from work around 6:00 AM. Themother changed the child’s diaper and the children ate breakfast. The children appearedsleepy, so the mother fell asleep with the victim child on the couch and the child’s2017 2nd Quarter Fatalities/Near FatalitiesApril 1 to June 30, 2017 10sibling went to sleep with the father. Around 8:30 AM, the father woke up and found hispill boxes, each of which had a week’s worth of medication in it, on the bedroom floor.One of the boxes was completely empty, another had half eaten/melted pills around it.The father realized the children were still sleeping which was uncharacteristic of them.The mother tried to wake up the children and found the child’s sibling was very drowsyand the victim child was unresponsive. Both children were taken to a local hospital. Thevictim child was transferred via medical helicopter to a specialized pediatric hospital.The child was unresponsive upon arrival. He was revived and observed for several hours.It was reported by the medical staff that the child and his sibling were at risk of seizuresand excessive bleeding due to the ingestion of the father’s medications. There are noother children in the home. The victim child was released to his mother’s care upon discharge from the hospital on February 9, 2017. A safety plan was established wherebythe maternal grandmother cares for the children while the mother works and all of thefather’s medications will be placed in either a safe or a lock box. The father is supervisedby the paternal grandmother when the children are in his care. The family had no priorinvolvement with CCCYS, however, per the local hospital, this was reportedly the secondincident where the child ingested the father’s medication. Criminal charges are pendingon the father. The case was not accepted for services due to mother’s protectivecapacities. The family was recommended to continue to utilize community resources. The agency closed the case on April 7, 2017.Delaware County

19. A 3-year-old male nearly died on February 18, 2017, as a result of serious physicalneglect. Delaware County Children and Youth Services (DCCYS) indicated the case onApril 19, 2017, naming the father as perpetrator. The mother was working and was nothome at the time of the incident. The father called emergency medical services after the

the child had ingested a Suboxone tablet on the evening of February 17, 2017. The childwas transported to the local hospital. The child was under observation for a 24-hourperiod due to his altered mental status. He became increasingly less responsive with adecreased respiratory rate. Narcan was administered. He was then transferred andadmitted to a specialized children’s hospital and was stabilized. The child tested positivefor cocaine. Both parents also tested positive for cocaine, however, the father was thesole caretaker of the child at the time of the incident. DCCYS placed the child with afamily member during the investigation. No other children resided in the home. Criminalcharges were brought against the father for endangering the welfare of a child. He isawaiting a trial date. The child was adjudicated dependent on March 13, 2017, and thefamily was accepted for ongoing services. The family had no prior history with DCCYS.Erie County 20. A 4-month-old female child nearly died on March 13, 2017, as a result of seriousphysical neglect. Erie County Office of Children and Youth (ECOCY) indicated this reporton April 17, 2017, naming the mother and her paramour as the perpetrators. On March13, 2017, the child was brought to a local hospital with a significant full body rash thathad turned into cellulitis. The child was found to be dehydrated and was administeredIV fluids and IV antibiotic. She was then transported to the regional children’s hospital.The treating physician diagnosed the child with severe uncontrolled eczema withseborrheic dermatitis that was infected with staph aureus, which was the cause of thechild’s sepsis. The victim child spent several weeks in the intensive care unit. The2017 2nd Quarter Fatalities/Near FatalitiesApril 1 to June 30, 2017 11physicians determined the child had contracted cellulitis and sepsis due to not receivingtimely medical treatment for her uncontrolled eczema and seborrheic dermatitis withimpetigo. The mother and her paramour were determined to be the sole caretakers of thechild. Both stated they were unable to provide medical care due to lack oftransportation. The child’s treating physician stated that this level of infection wouldhave been manifesting for a long time, and that the child was near death when she wasbrought to the local hospital. ECOCY obtained legal custody of the child on March 14, March 23, 2017. The child was discharged to foster care on March 29, 2017. ECOCY isproviding reunification services to the mother and her paramour. The criminalinvestigation is ongoing. ECOCY had no prior involvement with this family.Fayette County

21. A 2-year-old female child nearly died on February 5, 2017, as a result of seriousphysical neglect. Fayette County Children and Youth Services (FCCYS) indicated thereport on April 5, 2017, naming the mother as the perpetrator. On the date of incident,the child reportedly ingested Subutex. The mother observed her prescription bottle hadbeen opened and the child had a pill in her mouth. The medication was stored on theback of the kitchen sink in close proximity to the child’s candy jar, which she hadaccess to using a kitchen chair. It was unclear at the time how much of the Subutex thechild had ingested. The mother transported the child to the hospital due to the childappearing drowsy. The physicians gave the child a small amount of Narcan to stimulateher and she was transferred to a children’s hospital where she was found to be incritical condition. FCCYS assessed the safety of the four siblings. The mother voluntarilyplaced the four siblings with the maternal grandmother. When the child was releasedfrom the hospital on February 7, 2017, she was voluntarily placed with her siblings. Theplan remained in effect until the conclusion of the investigation and a dependencyhearing was held. The hearing was held on April 21, 2017, granting dependency of thechildren with their return to their mother’s care. The case remains open with FCCYS. Atthis time law enforcement has an ongoing investigation. The mother was referred for asubstance use assessment and intensive in-home services were initiated. FCCYS hadprior involvement with the family. There were seven prior general protective servicesreferrals beginning in 2013 that involved allegations of substance use by the parents.Three of these reports were screened out, three were assessed and closed at the intake level, and one was accepted for services from September 2015 to March 2016.Forest County

22. An 11-month-old male child nearly died on June 7, 2017, as a result of serious physicalneglect. Forest County Children and Youth Services (FCCYS) substantiated the case onJune 30, 2017, naming the child’s mother as the perpetrator. On June 7, 2017, atapproximately 1:10 PM, the mother and father transported the child to the local hospitaldue to him being lethargic. While at the hospital, the child was non-responsive and hadpinpoint pupils. The parents initially reported the child had fallen off the bed around7:00 AM. The victim child received a computerized axial tomography (CAT) scan, whichwas negative. Given the child’s condition he was provided a dose of Narcan. The childresponded but could not stay awake. The child was transferred via medical helicopter tothe regional pediatric hospital. Upon arrival, the victim child was blue in the face, had alow heart rate, and shallow breathing. He was able to be resuscitated with three doses ofNarcan. The child was placed on a Narcan drip and he regained full consciousness. The2017 2nd Quarter Fatalities/Near FatalitiesApril 1 to June 30, 2017 12mother later admitted that she had found her purse on the living room floor andapproximately six to eight of her Clonidine pills were lying on the floor. It wasdetermined the child had ingested at least one of these pills. The child remained hospitalized until June 8, 2017. Due to concerns with both the mother and father, asafety plan was developed. Upon discharge from the hospital, the parents voluntarilyagreed to place the child with the maternal grandmother in Crawford County with hissibling who had been placed there at the time of the incident. The family was acceptedfor services by Crawford County Children and Youth Services (CCCYS) and referrals forearly childhood programs and substance use assessments were scheduled. The motherhas not been criminally charged for this incident. Both Forest and Crawford Countieshad involvement with this family prior to this incident. From 2012 to 2015, FCCYSreceived four general protective services (GPS) reports regarding alleged domesticviolence, drug use by the parents and inadequate housing. As a result, the mother andsibling went to the maternal grandmother’s in Crawford County. In June 2016, CCCYSreceived a GPS report when the victim child was born due to the child testing positive forbenzodiazepines. At the time, the mother and the sibling were living with the maternalgrandmother in Crawford County. The agency determined that the mother was adequately meeting the children’s needs and closed the case in August 2016.Greene County

23. An 11-year-old female child nearly died on March 23, 2017, as a result of seriousphysical neglect. Greene County Children and Youth Services (GCCYS) indicated thecase on May 17, 2017, naming the child’s mother and father as the perpetrators. OnMarch 23, 2017, the child contacted her mother, who lives in another residence,stressing she felt ill. The child has a history of unstable glucose readings due to Type IDiabetes. The mother transported the child to a local hospital for treatment. Due to theseverity of her symptoms, the child was transferred to the local regional pediatrichospital. The child was diagnosed with diabetic ketoacidosis and remained hospitalized until March 28, 2017. The physicians felt the child’s condition occurred over a longperiod of time, and both parents share responsibility in caring for the child. Upondischarge, the child was placed into foster care. The mother explained she hadknowledge the child was ill for three days prior to seeking medical treatment. The fatherwas the caretaker for the child during these three days and had knowledge the child wasnot feeling well. The child has two siblings who were determined to be safe in the father’scare and remained in his residence. During the adjudication hearing on April 12, 2017,the victim child was declared dependent and returned to her father’s care. The family isreceiving ongoing services from GCCYS regarding diabetes education. No lawenforcement involvement occurred. GCCYS has a history with the family from August2011 to present, with seven general protective services referrals due to truancy, housingconditions and mother’s substance use. The case was opened for truancy and drug andalcohol services on two separate occasions. The children were in agency custody fromFebruary 11, 2016, to June 9, 2017, due to the children’s truancy issues, and themother’s drug and alcohol issues. The children were returned to the father’s care oncehousing was secured.Lackawanna County

24. A 7-month-old male child nearly died on February 26, 2017, as a result of seriousphysical neglect. Lackawanna County Office of Youth and Family Services (LCOYFS)indicated the case on April 5, 2017, naming the child’s parents as the perpetrators. The2017 2nd Quarter Fatalities/Near FatalitiesApril 1 to June 30, 2017 13child was admitted to a local hospital on February 26, 2017, and then transferred to aspecialized hospital for further evaluation. Upon admission, the child was found to beseverely malnourished and suffering from severe metabolic derangements. In addition,there were multiple abrasions on his face, arm and leg, and raw/denuded skin in hisgenital region. Medical records indicated that the child had only two doctorappointments since his discharge from the hospital after birth. At the time of theincident there was a 2-year-old male sibling residing in the home. Due to the conditionof the victim child, LCOYFS obtained custody of both children. The child’s sibling wasplaced in the kinship home of the paternal grandfather on February 27, 2017, and thechild was discharged from a pediatric rehabilitation facility to the kinship home on May 10, 2017. The family was opened for services to assist with parenting, residentialstability, employment, medical oversight, and behavioral health and substance usetreatment. The victim child currently receives occupational therapy, physical therapy,and therapy for possible speech delays. Both parents were charged with endangering thewelfare of a child and recklessly endangering another person. The father was arrested onMarch 25, 2017, and released on his own recognizance. The mother was arrested onMarch 24, 2017, and remained incarcerated until she was able to make bail. Thefather’s bail restrictions require him to have no contact with his children. The mother isable to participate in supervised visitation. LCOYFS had prior involvement with this family, including six reports from 2005 to 2016. In 2005, the family was referred due toconcerns regarding the parents' ability to provide care for a child who was born withbirth defects and declared “brain dead” shortly after birth. The sibling was placed in amedical group home and the child’s father obtained custody of him. In 2008, a referralwas received regarding substance use by the parents. The case was closed at intakeafter ensuring protective capacities. In 2008, the mother was indicated for abuse due toa sibling suffering a bone fracture. The sibling was placed with the paternalgrandparents. In November 2015, a referral was received regarding a sibling being bornexhibiting withdrawal symptoms. The mother had been prescribed Subutex, and thecase was closed at intake. A referral was received in 2015 regarding the sibling residingwith the paternal grandparents displaying inappropriate sexual behaviors. Thegrandparents were able to provide appropriate safety and supervision of the sibling, andthe case was closed at intake. In August 2016, a referral was received when the victimchild was born with withdrawal symptoms due to the mother’s prescribed use ofSubutex. The child remained in the hospital for a month and was then discharged to theparents as no safety concerns were identified and the physicians had no concernsregarding the child. The case was closed at intake.Lancaster County

25. A 2-week-old male nearly died on March 29, 2017, as a result of a physical abuse.Lancaster County Children and Youth Services indicated the case on May 26, 2017,naming the child’s father as the perpetrator. On March 28, 2017, the father reportedchanging his son’s diaper. While holding his leg down, he heard a pop. The child wasseen at a nearby hospital and was admitted and treated for a broken femur. A doctorcertified the child to be in serious or critical condition. According to medical staff, abroken femur can only occur when extreme force is applied. The father stated that hemay have applied too much force while holding down the child’s leg. There are no otherchildren residing in the home. The family was accepted and referred for services. Asafety plan remains in place; the father continues to reside outside the home and hisvisits with the child are supervised. The family was not known to the agency prior to thisincident.2017 2nd Quarter Fatalities/Near FatalitiesApril 1 to June 30, 2017 14Lehigh County

26. A 10-year-old female child nearly died on February 21, 2017, as a result of seriousphysical neglect. Lehigh County Office of Children and Youth Services (LCOCYS)indicated the case on April 21, 2017, naming the child’s mother as the perpetrator. OnFebruary 19, 2017, the child was taken to the hospital by her father. She was found tohave symptoms of nausea, vomiting, and hyperglycemia. The child was also diagnosedwith sleep apnea/tonsillar hypertrophy, vitamin D deficiency, premature adrenarche,hypertrophic and atrophic condition of the skin. During this hospitalization, the motherprovided inconsistent information to the medical staff and was insistent that the childshould be handling her own diabetic regimen. The child reported to hospital staff thatshe usually misses one dose of insulin per week; however, her laboratory valuesindicated she was missing doses more frequently. It was found that the child had missedseventeen appointments for endocrinology and intensive management since July 2015,missed ten pediatric clinic appointments since November 2015, and had been admittedto the intensive care unit six times in less than a year. The child reported that sheprimarily resided with her mother and had visits with her father. During theinvestigation, the mother admitted she had not supervised the child’s administration ofinsulin. She also admitted that the child figured out her own carbohydrate intake andmeasure of insulin. The mother stated she did not check the child’s blood sugar atbedtime as recommended medically. The father admitted that he did not have a plan ofcare for the child during his overnight work schedule and he did not make himselfavailable to the education provided by the hospital regarding diabetic care for hisdaughter. The child was adjudicated dependent and discharged to her godmother’s home on February 25, 2017. The godmother has experience in diabetic care. The child’sthree siblings remained with the mother as there were no safety concerns regarding theircare. No charges have been filed. LCOCYS had had prior involvement with this family.One general protective services (GPS) referral in December 2013 and one GPS in October2014 were received for substance use, domestic violence, and lack of medical insurance.The family was opened for ongoing services from October 2014 through May 2015 forissues related to the child’s diabetes. From September 2015 to January 2017, four GPSreferrals were received for domestic violence issues and concerns of substandardhousing. The family was referred to services between November 2016 and January 2017with focus on housing assistance.Luzerne County

27. A 5-year-old female child nearly died on April 17, 2017, as a result of serious physicalneglect. Luzerne County Children and Youth Services (LCCYS) indicated the case on May15, 2017, naming the child’s mother as the perpetrator for failing to provide the childwith proper medical care. The child had been seen by her primary care physician onApril 14, 2017, when the mother was instructed to take the child to the emergency roomfor treatment. The mother waited until three days later to take the child to the localhospital due to flu-like symptoms and the child being “out of it.” The child wastransferred to a pediatric specialty hospital for further treatment of diabetic ketoacidosis(DKA). The mother denied noncompliance with the child’s diabetes management statingthat the child was sick and not keeping anything down, including insulin. The twotreating physicians stated that the spike in the child’s blood sugar level occurredbecause the mother was not giving the child the proper amounts of insulin. The childentered foster care upon discharge from the hospital. The child’s 3-year-old sibling2017 2nd Quarter Fatalities/Near FatalitiesApril 1 to June 30, 2017 15remains in the home as there are no concerns for his safety in the care of his mother.LCCYS continues to provide ongoing support and services to the family includingvisitation, substance use treatment, parenting and diabetes education. The child attendsa pediatric day health center. Mother’s visitation with the child occurs at the healthcenter where she receives diabetes education for the care of her daughter. There were nocriminal charges filed as a result of this incident. The family has a history of involvement with LCCYS. There were four prior referrals received by LCCYS between 2012 and 2017.At the time of the incident, the case was open with LCCYS after two 2017 referrals werereceived regarding concerns with the child’s diabetic care. The case had been opened since March 30, 2017.McKean County

28. A 4-month-old female child nearly died on April 3, 2017, as a result of physical abuse.McKean County Children and Youth Services (MCCYS) indicated the case on June 1,2017, naming the child’s babysitter as the perpetrator. On April 3, 2017, the motherarrived home from work at 9:30 PM, and discovered the child was not responding tostimuli. She transported the child to the local hospital. A computerized axial tomographyscan determined the child had sustained an acute subdural hematoma and retinalhemorrhages along with evidence of an older subdural hematoma. The child wastransported via ambulance to a larger regional hospital. Medical testing confirmed thechild had injuries consistent with Shaken Baby Syndrome. The mother had left for workat 2:00 PM on April 3, 2017, leaving the child in the care of the babysitter. The child didnot exhibit any abnormalities prior to the mother leaving for work. The babysitter wasinconsistent in his interviews, and some of the claims he made were refuted byphotographic evidence. The child’s 3-year-old sister who was also cared for by thebabysitter did not have any injuries. A safety plan was put in place that resulted in thematernal grandmother caring for the sibling while the victim child was hospitalized. Themother and the children now live with the maternal grandmother. No charges had beenfiled. The child currently receives early intervention services, home health care as well asphysical, occupational, and speech therapies. MCCYS closed the case at the conclusionof the investigation. No charges have been filed on the babysitter. MCCYS had no priorinvolvement with this family.Monroe County

29. A 1-month-old male child nearly died on April 13, 2017, as a result of physical abuse.Monroe County Children and Youth Services (MCCYS) indicated the case on May 30,2017, naming the child’s mother as the perpetrator. On April 13, 2017, the victim childwas taken to a local hospital by his mother with symptoms of lethargy and refusing toeat. The examination revealed that the child had multiple bruises, a bruised eye, andbrain hematomas, a skull fracture, and had new and healed fractures. The victim childwas certified to be in critical condition and transferred to a regional hospital. The motherreported that the victim child was dropped on the floor by his 6-year-old sibling thatmorning and slept through the day while the family was on a shopping trip for seven toeight hours. The physician confirmed that the victim child’s injuries could not have beensustained as reported by the perpetrator. The mother later admitted to striking the child.The child has three siblings that were also residing in the home. The siblings weremedically evaluated, and it was determined that they had no prior or current injuries.Due to the severity of the victim child’s injuries, all four children were placed in the custody of MCCYS via emergency shelter care order on April 13, 2017. The mother was2017 2nd Quarter Fatalities/Near FatalitiesApril 1 to June 30, 2017 16arrested on thirteen different charges, nine of which are felonies, related to the injuriesof the victim child and is currently incarcerated. The father was incarcerated at the timeof the incident on unrelated charges and remains incarcerated. The victim child wasdischarged from the hospital and placed in a foster home for medically fragile children.He is receiving early intervention services. The siblings are placed together in a differentfoster home and are receiving case management services. The oldest sibling is beingevaluated for behavioral health services. The agency has made referrals through theInterstate Office for the children to be placed with either the maternal or paternalgrandparents. MCCYS had prior involvement with this family from April 2015 through September 2016. Two siblings were placed in the custody of the agency from April 2015to February 2016 due to parental drug use and criminal drug activity in the home. Themother was charged with child endangerment. The mother was residing in another stateat the time, and the children were returned home to the mother through the Interstate Office after the mother’s child endangerment charges were dismissed in February 2016.The father of the children was arrested and charged with drug-related criminal offensesand was incarcerated. In March 2016, MCCYS learned that the family moved back toMonroe County. In September 2016, the case was closed after the parents demonstrateda substantial period of sobriety and were able to maintain employment and housing.Perry County

30. A 5-month-old male child nearly died on February 18, 2017, as a result of physicalabuse. Perry County Children and Youth (PCCYS) indicated the case on April 14, 2017,naming the child’s father as the perpetrator. On February 18, 2017, the victim child wasreportedly fussy between 1:00 AM and 6:00 AM, at which time the mother fed the victimchild and then the mother went back to bed. The father took the victim child downstairsand put him in a baby seat and the father fell asleep. The father woke up to hear thebaby gasping and appearing limp. The father woke the mother and they called 911 at7:26 AM. The victim child was transported by ambulance to the regional hospital. Thevictim child was admitted to the intensive care unit with a skull fracture and subduralhematoma. Law enforcement officials were notified. When interviewed, the father statedthat the victim child rolled off the couch on the afternoon of February 16, 2017, onto ahardwood floor but was fine afterwards. The mother was at work at that time as well asthe next day. On February 20, 2017, the father reported that he had thrown the victimchild onto the couch and the victim child had hit the wooden bar across the back of thecouch. The father stated that he was agitated and frustrated when dealing with thevictim child. Law enforcement officials arrested and charged the father with aggravatedassault, aggravated assault on victim less than 13, aggravated assault on victim lessthan 6, simple assault, endangering the welfare of children, and recklessly endangeringanother person. The father was released on bail. Three siblings in the home went to stay with a maternal aunt to ensure safety on February 20, 2017. During the investigation,the parents separated. The father moved out of the home and the victim child’s siblings returned to the mother on April 13, 2017. Family preservation services were instituted.The victim child was adjudicated dependent, and upon release from the hospital wasplaced into foster care. The father was court-ordered to have no contact with the victimchild and supervised visits with the victim child’s siblings. PCCYS had prior involvementwith this family. In June 2011, a general protective services (GPS) referral was receivedregarding inappropriate care of the children and unstable housing. After assessment and supportive services were received, the referral was closed in August 2011. FromNovember 2011 to February 2013, three GPS reports were screened out.2017 2nd Quarter Fatalities/Near FatalitiesApril 1 to June 30, 2017 17Philadelphia County

31. A 13-year-old male nearly died on May 22, 2017, as a result of serious physical neglect.Philadelphia Department of Human Services (PDHS) indicated the case on June 22,2017, naming the child’s mother and father as the perpetrators. The mother and fatherfailed to recognize the child’s deteriorating condition, failed to intervene knowing thechild did not check his blood levels, and failed to seek medical care. The victim child was diagnosed with Type 1 diabetes in September 2015. He has a history of suicidal ideationand depression and poorly controlled insulin management. The parents do not reside inthe same household, but co-parent and expect the child to monitor his own insulinneeds without parental supervision. On May 22, 2017, the child’s mother found thevictim child unresponsive and incontinent. The mother transported the child to the localchildren’s hospital where he was found to have severe diabetic ketoacidosis and analtered mental status. Physicians found him to be at imminent risk for neurologicaldeterioration, respiratory deterioration, and life-threatening electrolyte abnormalities.The parents were aware that the child was not himself for three to four days prior to theincident, however, they did not seek medical attention for the child. On May 23, 2017,the mother removed the child from the hospital against medical advice, returning thenext day. A safety plan was implemented which restricted the parent’s visitation. Thechild was discharged and placed into kinship care with his adult half-sister and herhusband due to concerns of the parent’s unrealistic developmental expectations for thevictim child as well as their minimalizing the seriousness of his disease. The child andhis caregivers are compliant with his medical regime and treatment. The parents haveliberal visitation supervised by the kinship caregiver. Two siblings in the home weremedically evaluated and cleared. The family is receiving in-home services. Lawenforcement was not involved in this incident. The family was known to PDHS. OnJanuary 15, 2003, a report was received when an older sibling was physically abused bythe mother. The report was indicated naming mother as the perpetrator. The family

32. An 8-year-old female child nearly died on March 13, 2017, as a result of physical abuse.Philadelphia Department of Human Services (PDHS) indicated the case on April 7, 2017,naming the child’s mother as the perpetrator. On March 13, 2017, the family memberstook a nap around 4:00 or 4:30 PM. The mother and victim child’s sister woke uparound 7:00 PM but the victim child did not wake up. The mother stated that when sheattempted to wake the child she observed empty medication bottles lying near the bed.She placed the victim in the tub, began running cold water, and then called emergencymedical services. The child arrived at the hospital in an unconscious state. The mothercould not give a reliable explanation as to why the child was unconscious. Narcan wasadministered and the child was revived. According to the toxicology report, the childtested positive for cocaine, opiates, Trilipix and Tylenol. The mother stated that shekeeps medication in a medicine cabinet and believes the child may have takensomething for stress. The mother denied using any illegal drugs and stated she was inrecovery. Her most recent drug screen in February 2017 was negative for substances.She could give no explanation as to how the child obtained the illegal substance. Thechild’s sibling was placed in kinship care while the victim child was transferred to arehabilitation center. On April 5, 2017, the victim child was placed in the same kinshiphome. On June 16, 2017, the mother was arrested and charged with endangering the welfare of a child. The trial was scheduled for July 24, 2017. The family was opened forcase management services, counseling services, parenting education, and substance useservices. The family has prior involvement with PDHS. In May 2007, mother was2017 2nd Quarter Fatalities/Near FatalitiesApril 1 to June 30, 2017 18indicated for injuring the child’s sibling while intoxicated. The family received in-homeservices. In March 2009, a general protective services report was received alleging thevictim child was not receiving appropriate care and the mother was using substances inthe presence of the baby. The report was investigated and determined invalid and thecase was not accepted for services.

33. A 4-year-old male child nearly died on May 3, 2017, as a result of physical abuse.Philadelphia Department of Human Services (PDHS) indicated the case on June 29,2017, naming the child’s mother and paramour as the perpetrators. On May 3, 2017,the child was taken to the babysitter’s house at 6:00 AM. Approximately 15 minuteslater the babysitter observed the child to wobble and fall to the ground and begin to have a seizure. The babysitter contacted 9-1-1. The child was taken to a local hospital wherea computed axial tomography (CAT) scan revealed a skull fracture on the right side ofhis head including a hematoma and a midline shift. A medical evaluation revealed thechild also suffered a rib fracture and multiple bruises. The child was then transferred toa specialized pediatric hospital. The mother and her paramour, who were responsible forthe care and well-being of the child, could not give a reliable explanation as to how thechild sustained the injuries. The mother reported the child had hurt his head on April 4,2017, and was taken to a pediatric hospital; however, a CAT scan was performed, andno fracture was reported. The child was unable to reliably articulate details as to howthe injuries occurred. The half-sibling was placed in foster care to ensure her safety. Thevictim child transitioned to a rehabilitation center and then to a medical foster home in July 2017. A criminal investigation is ongoing, and charges have not been filed. Themother and paramour were referred to parenting services as well as case managementservices. Both the mother and her paramour are not to visit the child until he ismedically cleared. The mother and her paramour are participating in weekly supervisedvisits with the child’s half-sibling. The family was known to PDHS prior to this incident.The mother was known as a child. The father, mother and paramour were investigatedin the 2011 death of a 6-month-old child of the mother and father. The cause of deathwas determined to be accidental.

34. A 4-year-old male child nearly died on February 14, 2017, as a result of physical abuse.Philadelphia Department of Human Services (PDHS) indicated the case on April 4, 2017,naming the maternal uncle as the perpetrator. The child resided in the home of hisfather. The father reported that either on February 13 or 14, 2017, he took the child tothe maternal uncle’s home for child care while he went to work. The father stated thathe received a telephone call from the maternal uncle on February 14, 2017, reportingthat the child had a little burn due to bath water being hot, but the father did not needto rush to get the child and the child did not need to go to the hospital. When the fatherreturned on February 17, 2017, he saw the child had socks on his hands covering theburns. The father called emergency services. The child was taken to a children’s hospitaland then transferred to a specialized hospital. The father stated he had not known theburns were severe. The maternal uncle stated that he left the child in the tub notknowing that the water was extremely hot. Medical reports indicate that the childsustained second degree burns covering 24 percent of his body. There were no splashpatterns to the burns, which indicated that someone held the child down in the water.On March 17, 2017, the child’s father, his maternal uncle, and the paramour of thematernal uncle were arrested and charged with aggravated assault, endangering thewelfare of a child, simple assault, and recklessly endangering another person. On April21, 2017, the child’s father was released on bail. The maternal uncle and the paramourof the maternal uncle remain incarcerated. They were scheduled for a pre-trial hearing2017 2nd Quarter Fatalities/Near FatalitiesApril 1 to June 30, 2017 19 in August 2017. The victim child was discharged from the rehabilitation center on April24, 2017, and placed into medical kinship care. The child has three siblings that are also in kinship care. The PDHS had prior involvement with this family since 2011. Mostrecently, a child protective services (CPS) report was received in October 2016, however,no safety threats were identified, and the child was determined to be safe. The case was closed in November 2016. In January 2017, a CPS report alleged that the father had cutthe victim child on his face with scissors. It was alleged that the father was using drugs,had a criminal history, and had taken the victim child away from the mother. A custodyhearing concerning the victim child was scheduled for April 2017 where it wasdetermined that there were no safety threats in the home of the victim child’s mother. Atthe time of the incident PDHS had been attempting to locate the victim child and hisfather since January 2017 to no avail until the report of the child’s hospitalization wasreceived.Schuylkill County

35. A 23-day-old female child nearly died on April 29, 2017, as a result of physical abuse.Schuylkill County Children and Youth Services (SCCYS) indicated the case on June 6,2017, naming an unknown person as the perpetrator. On April 27, 2017, the motherexpressed concern to the child’s primary care physician (PCP) that the child was“sleeping with her eyes open.” The PCP suggested an overnight admittance to thehospital for observation, but the mother declined. On April 28, 2017, the child was againseen by the PCP with no specified concerns. On April 29, 2017, the child begandisplaying some seizure-like activity. The PCP again recommended admission to thehospital and the mother agreed. Prior to admission, a computerized axial tomography(CAT) scan was conducted revealing a mildly depressed fracture of the left frontal bone,suggestive of trauma, and swelling of the brain. At that time, the child was certified incritical condition and was flown by helicopter to a medical center. The child remained in the hospital until May 2, 2017. During the investigation, the parents were unable toexplain how the injury had occurred. On April 29, 2017, a safety plan was implementedfor the three siblings in the home to reside with relatives until the investigation wasconcluded. During the investigation, it was learned that there had been an incidentduring which the child had been strapped in a car seat that was placed on a coffee table.One of the siblings accidentally knocked the seat off the table. The parents and thesiblings reported that the child did not appear hurt following that incident, but it didoccur a week or so prior to the child exhibiting the head injury symptoms. Both parentstook a polygraph test and passed. As a result, the children were returned to them. Theagency opened the case for intensive case management services. The parents have bothrecently tested positive for methamphetamines, and have now been referred for drug andalcohol evaluations. The child has been doing well and the parents have been able tomeet all the children’s medical needs. SCCYS has prior involvement with this family.From September 2006 until February 2011, six child protective services referrals werereceived regarding alleged drug use by the parents, domestic violence, and supervisionissues. All were closed at intake. In December 2011, the oldest sibling was placed withthe father due to the mother’s paramour’s drug use and domestic violence issues. FromFebruary 2013 to August 2014, four general protective services referrals were receivedand closed for custody issues related to the oldest child. In January 2015 and again inJune 2016, there were allegations of domestic violence and unsuitable home conditionswith the father and the mother of the victim child. These were unsubstantiated andclosed. In March 2017, concerns were reported regarding allegations of substance use,verbal abuse of the children, and the victim child withdrawing from Suboxone at birth.2017 2nd Quarter Fatalities/Near FatalitiesApril 1 to June 30, 2017 20The family was being assessed for services when this incident occurred. The family iscurrently open for services to monitor the victim child’s medical care, weight gain, andfurther assessment of parental drug use. No criminal charges have been filed at thistime.

36. A 22-month-old female child nearly died on April 9, 2017, as a result of serious physicalneglect. Schuylkill County Children and Youth Services (SCCCYS) indicated the case onMay 9, 2017, naming the child’s mother, father, and caregiver as the perpetrators. OnApril 9, 2017, the child was found chewing a methamphetamine bag in the home wherethe family resided. The child was monitored by the mother and the father for some time until she started to display seizure-like behavior, resulting in the parents calling 9-1-1.The child was flown via air-ambulance to a regional hospital and was listed in criticalcondition with an unknown prognosis. The child tested positive for methamphetamine,amphetamine and methylenedioxy-methamphetamine (MDMA). When she arrived at thehospital she was in tachycardia, with a very high heart rate. The child was sedated tocontrol her heart rate and was on a ventilator to control her breathing. The child waslisted in critical condition. The parents reportedly appeared to be under the influence atthe time of the incident. At the time of the incident the caregiver was not present in thehome. There was a court ordered safety plan in place for the family stating that thecaregiver would not allow any unsupervised contact between the father and the child,and would not allow the father to reside in the home. During the investigation, it wasfound that the father was residing in the home. Both parents denied usingmethamphetamine, but later the mother did admit she had used on April 8 to April 9, 2017. Both parents stated they had no knowledge as to how the child accessed thedrugs. The caregiver reported that prior to leaving the home on the date of the incident,she saw the parents and the child sleeping on the first floor of the home. The parentswere charged with aggravated assault, simple assault, possession of drugs, endangeringthe welfare of a child and reckless endangerment, and were incarcerated. The child’smother and caregiver also failed to follow through with a court-ordered safety plan byallowing the father in the home and unsupervised access to the victim child. The motherwas incarcerated and released in May 2017 and immediately entered a psychiatricfacility. The child was placed in foster care upon her discharge from the hospital. AnInterstate Compact referral has been made for the maternal grandfather to become akinship home for the victim child. SCCYS has had prior involvement with this family. InJuly 2013, a referral was made regarding concerns of the parent’s drug use, unstablehousing, and the basic needs of the sibling not being met. The case was open fromSeptember 2013 until July 2014 when it was closed after custody of the sibling wastransferred to the maternal grandfather. The second referral was received on June 12,2015, when the victim child was born due to concerns of domestic violence and theparents’ lack of coping skills. The case was opened for services on August 10, 2015, andcontinued to be open at the time of the incident. The family was receiving parenting,drug and alcohol, and mental health counseling services, however, participation andcompliance was sporadic. The victim child’s basic and medical needs were being met. Asafety plan was in place indicating the father would reside outside the home and allcontact with the child would be supervised.York County

37. A 2-month-old male child nearly died on March 31, 2017, as a result of physical abuse.On May 16, 2017, York County Children, Youth and Families (YCCYF) indicated thefather as the perpetrator. On March 31, 2017, the father stated he heard the child2017 2nd Quarter Fatalities/Near FatalitiesApril 1 to June 30, 2017 21crying around 4:00 AM and called the paternal grandparents and the child’s mother forassistance. The paternal grandfather went to the home to help, but the child continuedto cry. The child’s mother arrived home from work at about 6:00 AM and the mother andfather took the child to the local hospital. A computerized axial tomography (CAT) scandetermined the child had a brain bleed and severe bruising to the left side of his head.On May 30, 2017, the child was transferred to a medical center. Neither parent couldprovide an explanation for the injuries. On April 3, 2017, the child was released from themedical center and YCCYF placed him with a family friend on a safety plan. A few dayslater the family friend stated she was not comfortable supervising contact between thechild and father. The child was then placed in the care of his paternal grandparents.During the investigation, the father had stated he dropped the child, however, a hospitalphysician stated the injuries were not consistent with a fall. A few weeks later the fatherinformed law enforcement that he had slapped the child in the face because the childwould not stop crying. He also admitted to being intoxicated the night of the incident.The father was charged with aggravated assault and endangering the welfare of a child.He is currently incarcerated and awaiting his hearing. Neither parent has any otherchildren. The victim child remains in the care of his paternal grandparents who havebeen approved as formal kinship caregivers. The child has been assessed and has beenfound to be on track developmentally, however, due to his injuries he may be monitoredto ensure that no concerns develop. The mother is participating in a parenting program.The goal is for the victim child to return to his mother’s care and custody. He hassupervised visitation with his mother several times per week. While incarcerated, thefather is to be participating in parenting, substance use treatment, and angermanagement courses. The family was not known to YCCYF prior to this near fatality.
